SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use separate sheets of paper if there is insufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events; if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pictorial History of Western Canadian Pioneers Era?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing and chores
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

Morrison, Norman Spalding,

To Sask., April, 1904.
Morrison, Norman Spalding.

To Sask. - April, 1904.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and places named in capital letters. If you do not have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Morrison, Norman Spalding.
2. Your address: 244, S.A.S.K.
3. Date: June 25, 1904.
4. Where were you born? Island of Harris, Scotland.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Donald Macintosh, Fisherman.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) April 1904.
7. Mention any other places where you have lived before coming to Saskatchewan. (Give month and year)
   - April 1904, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.
8. How would you describe yourself when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you are not sure.)
   - Young, single, hardworking, strong.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? To acquire a homestead.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

Through government and railroad circulars.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was foolish.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)? Yes, Adamson Government Agent advertised for farm workers, so I went along.

13. What means of transportation did you use? By steamship and railway.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? People you met on the way, the excitement of seeing students at school.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Northam - where the old settlers' homes were located.

16. Where did you settle or make upland? Northam - 88-89 acres.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Tryland from 1916 to 1918.

18. How did you earn a living before coming off the farm entirely after coming? On a farm, mostly before coming off the farm entirely after coming.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Not often

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Elizabeth Thomson - 1909 at Humboldt, Sask.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   No

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   None came

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   None

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Did not travel much, when I did, it was by oxen first, then horses, and then by car.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1912

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Watson, 14 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   continued to trade there until 1920 when CPR built a line from Lanigan to Melrose; our new town was Fielding

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Once or twice a week

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   About 1930

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   1909 - Furniture - Mostly Clothing 20% Now 50%

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Fielding Rural Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Came prepared to stay permanently if possible
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, quite a number left after homesteading.

Reason—success seemed hopeless.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Not many moved out during the 30's.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

The writer was Secretary for the Local Improvement District from 1906 till the District was formed into a Municipality around 1911-12.

Was Secretary of Sunnyview S & D from 1919 till 1943.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

Organized the first Backgammon Growers Lodge around 1910 and was Secretary, and helped organize Co-op Elevator Pool. Mrs Morrison organized the first Poultry Pool Local in this District and later was President for years of the Provincial Organization.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given (5) date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (2), (3), (4).

The name of our first Post Office was Beauchamp and was called after the man on whose land the Post Office was situated. The name of the present Post Office is Spalding and is called after a town in England named Spalding. Mr. D.W. Hutchison, merchant, was the person who suggested the name, there never was any change.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? ......
(indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.
We have two sons and one daughter.
Donald married has one daughter lives at Victoria, B.C.
Angus married no children, Catherine married, two daughters both lives in Galding.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?
The Railway, The Telephone, The Mechanized Brushcutter, Tractor, Motor Car and Combine

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.
Mr. J. W. Hutchison & ?
Galding, Sask.
